clinical_study.brief_title: COVID-19 Project ECHO in Nursing Homes
clinical_study.official_title: COVID-19 Project ECHO for Nursing Homes: A Patient-centered, Randomized-controlled Trial to Implement Infection Control and Quality of Life Best Practice

brief_summary.textblock: Nursing homes are ground zero for the COVID-19 pandemic.Pennsylvania (PA) nursing homes are particularly devastated with 13,485 cases of COVID-19 and more than 2,800 deaths, accounting for 65% of the state's coronavirus deaths. Nursing homes are ill-equipped for the pandemic; though facilities are required to have infection control staff, only 3% have taken a basic infection control course.Significant research has focused on infection control in the acute care setting.However,little is known about the implementation of practices and effective interventions in long-term care facilities.The investigators propose an intervention utilizing Project ECHO, an evidence-based telehealth model, to connect Penn State University experts with remote nursing home staff and administrators to proactively support evidence-based infection control guideline implementation. Our study seeks to answer the critical research question of how evidence-based infection control guidelines can be implemented effectively in nursing homes

detailed_description.textblock: The investigators will recruit 100 nursing homes with approximately 12,600 residents from across PA's 695 nursing homes through collaborations with our state stakeholders. Nursing homes will be randomized to one of two arms: COVID-19 Project ECHO (25 hours of training over 6 months), or the CDC infection control training (17 hours of training over 6 months). COVID-19 Project ECHO participants will include infection control staff and other facility leadership (e.g. medical director, director of nursing, administrators). Randomization will be stratified by characteristics of nursing homes to ensure balance among the two trial groups, including size (number of beds), type (independent vs. network facility), geographic location, and current COVID-19 infection rate. Patient-centered outcomes (nursing home residents with COVID-19 infections, hospitalizations, deaths, and QOL) will be assessed at baseline, 6, 12, and 18 months. All nursing homes can opt to receive the ECHO intervention in the last 6 months of the study. Our study is guided by the RE-AIM framework to critically evaluate both effectiveness and implementation outcomes of the proposed intervention. The RE-AIM framework is frequently utilized to improve sustainable adoption and implementation of effective, generalizable, evidence-based interventions like Project ECHO.

primary_outcome.description: Rate of COVID-19 infection in enrolled nursing homes

secondary_outcome.description: Number of COVID-19 hospitalizations from enrolled nursing homes
Number of COVID-19 deaths from enrolled nursing homes

arm_group.description: Nursing homes in this arm will receive the intervention via real-time, interactive videoconferencing using Zoom at no cost to participants. Sessions will be 60 minutes in duration and held weekly for 6 months (25 sessions total) at regularly scheduled times. Project ECHO utilizes case-based, collaborative learning to support discussion of learners' challenges and barriers to guideline implementation

Participants in the control group will be asked to complete CDC infection control training modules (https://www.cdc.gov/longtermcare/training.html). The CDC training course consists of 15 modules and 17 hours of training and is free for participants. Participants will be encouraged to complete this over a 6-month period.

intervention.description: Project ECHO utilizes case-based, collaborative learning to support discussion of learners' challenges and barriers to guideline implementation. This differentiates ECHO from traditional learning and facilitates rapid dissemination of medical knowledge and increased capacity to deliver best-practice care.studying innovative approaches.
CDC Infection Prevention Training consists of 15 modules and 17 hours of online self-paced modules.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria for Facilities Skilled Nursing Facility in Pennsylvania Access to computer or electronic device
Exclusion Criteria for Facilities Skilled nursing facility outside of Pennsylvania Previously participated in Project ECHO COVID-19 series either through Penn State or another institution, or has already completed the CDC infection control training modules
